Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Creating a respectful database of lost slave narratives; a lot of insights on black digital humanities projects
How to search databases, how to create a database, how to read a slave advertisement, how to understand/close read very intellectual papers.
I learned about various topics on runaway slaves as well as tools in digital humanities to study history.
This class was great in that it gave me the chance to gain a deeper knowledge into runaway slaves.
I learned so much more about slavery and how it can be represented digitally, if at all.
I learned a lot about the history of fugitives and freedom-seekers related to the U.S. slave trade and its legacy!
I learned a great deal about runaways in early America, along with some of the philosophy behind archives today, as well as how to create a database online.

Throughout this course, I developed a much more meaningful understanding of slavery in the 18th and 19th century. I learned much more about the logistics of where slaves ran to and what they ran from. I feel as though throughout this class I began to understand more about the history of runaway slaves in an engaged, interesting way.
Amazing course, no improvements needed.
An hour and fifty minutes is a long time...even if it's just once a week. It's hard to stay engaged that long. Class size was also a little large.
It should have been a smaller class and there should have been more involvement on the part of the professor. Readings were interesting though.

I loved how each week, we looked at a different topic involving runaway slavery; I thought it was really cool to study one thing through various different perspectives, and build upon previous discussions that we had earlier. I really enjoyed the final project; I thought it was a cool way to tie together everything we had done this semester. The one way I think the course could be improved is if the class size were slightly smaller; I really enjoyed the discussions we had in class, but I think they would be better if the class weren't so large.
Class presentations and lectures were great. The class project was a lot of fun.
There should be less people in this seminar. Also, this is a writing credit, but I can't say I learned how to write better at all.
Definitely keep seminars small

I really enjoyed the readings for this course, and I think the weekly reading responses were a good way to stay on track, but the size of the class made discussion difficult. I think it would have been in the professor's benefit to convert it into more of a discussion/lecture hybrid. Also, the database project was very cool, but I almost wish we had started it earlier, so our final product could have been more developed.

Strengths: Very interesting project, useful in getting students to think about clich topics in new and creative ways.

Weaknesses: A bit loose in subject matter; too large of a class size for a seminar-style to really work well.
I believe the only obvious weakness to this course was the fact that it only met once a week. I think that if this course were to be offered again It should be offered more days a week.
Definitely take
YES
Yeah. Great class and an interesting seminar topic.
Not unless the structure of the class changed so it was smaller and discussions were facilitated by the professor.

I would certainly recommend this course to anyone interested in the digital humanities. This class offered an in-depth look at runaway slaves, the experiences they had, and the communities they formed. Professor Yannielli was really passionate about the subject, and the class discussions were always interesting (albeit a bit slow sometimes).
I would recommend this class. I really enjoyed the readings each week and the discussions we had, and the course changed my perspective on how we study history.
Great class, you learn a lot and the work doesnt kill you.
Yes. Take it if you want to learn about the actual content of this course. Don't take it if you want to improve your writing skills.
Yes, it was incredibly interesting and engaging! One of the most unique classes I have taken at Yale, Rogues will definitely be one I remember.

I think with a few improvements this could be a great course. The material was very interesting, and the workload was very chill. The only problem was that there were way too many people for it to be a seminar, so discussion stagnated, though this got better once we began working on the database project.
I would definitely recommend this course to anybody who looks to gain knowledge of slavery from a new perspective, and gain insights that they had previously not been exposed to.
